poem:
**Swing Vote, Swing Time**

In Saginaw, where violins are silenced,
Lawns whisper secrets between the lines.
No signs, no shouts—just quiet blinds,
'Til calendar flips, our days defined.

Midwestern whispers, candidates' fate,
Silent tension in our bordered state.
Here's where decisions tip the scales,
Where quiet streets hold loudest tales.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Saginaw: the swing city in the swing state that could decide the election A local law says that residents of Saginaw Township in Michigan cannot publicly display political signs in support of a presidential candidate until 30 days before the US election, even on their own front lawns. But you wouldn’t know it while driving through this neat midwestern township that borders a town of the same name – simply, Saginaw – in the most". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
